title: Data protection legislation influence on cloud computing from local as well as EU perspective

author: Andrej Tomšič, Information Commissioner of the Republic of Slovenia, Government of the Republic of Slovenia

segmentation: Let me shortly introduce myself and the Deputy Commissioner from the Information Commissioner of Slovenia.
For those who do not know what the hell that is, it is the supervisory body for personal data protection in our country similar to 27 other EU countries.
We are the ones who tell the other side of the story, usually as soon as it comes to cloud computing and every other new developments that involve personal data.
The topic of my presentation will be.
As I said, the other side, what are some of the specific risks that cloud computing brings when we speak about protection of personal data?
What are the issues that the current legal framework has with these new concepts and are there any solutions in bringing those two apparently rather distant worlds together?
So as if we.
About the European approach to data protection.
Protection of personal data most mostly we are facing a rather outdated concept of two main pillars.
Firstly we have this so called data controller.
This is a legal or in some cases even natural person who determines the means and the process is and the resources for processing personal data.
So he's the one that defines the game.
So they say and as soon as he is not capable of doing something as good as it can be done.
He can, of course, employ the services of a contractual provider so called data processor.
In other words, an outsourcing partner.
And here, of course, should and act only on behalf of the data controller.
Of course, if you think of the cloud, the situation is somewhat rather different.
We can have a very small data controller and a very large data processor.
Take for example a small school or a small municipality and a cloud providers such as Google, Amazon and so on.
I think it's quite clear who is the one that has all the bargaining power and who can decide what will be the terms of use of his services.
It's in contrast with the the old, so to say concept from your data protection legislation where the data controller is the one in charge.
Of course, not all cloud, so to say.
Positions or specifics are the same when we speak about personal data, I think the higher concerns are involved mostly in the public cloud domain and not so high in the.
For example, a completely private cloud.

And of course the questions are arise as soon as you give up your control over your data, especially if this involves cross border transfers, particularly to third countries which do not have the same level of.
Protection is for example European Union, which is rather strict from that point of view.
The three main issues where the clash occurs are mostly the contractual processing of personal data, so this whole balance that is not there anymore.
The questions about data and information security and the question of legal grounds for exporting personal data to third countries.
How to breed?
Only touch up, touch up on some of those questions.
As I said already before, there's this huge discrepancy between the bargaining powers of a data controller.
An cloud provider, usually the small data controller, especially has no means to change or influence the terms of use.
He's given a standard terms of use by especially long large data processors.
And the question is OK, this is the current legislation.
Now what can we do about it?
Can we try to make it survive this huge sort of issues or challenges?

Or should we try to seek and find ways to get a new kind of balance that would still put the driver into control so that the one who is the data controller to have more saying about who does what with his personal data?
I think there is a lot to be done, especially on the side of transparency of cloud providers because currently they do not provide a lot of meaningful data two data controllers.
And sometimes they are left without any answers to the very basic questions.
Where will my personal later actually be stored, processed, transferred?
How will it be secured?
Will it be deleted ever?
I don't think does Google delete anything ever?

Nothing's alright, which is already a bit of a problem with data protection, I suppose because one of its main principle is that you should delete data on the once the purpose of processing was achieved, and so on.
And in most or not, most in some, let's say terms of use, you will see clauses like don't worry, you are client cloud clients.
But rest assured we will process personal data in line with our privacy policy, so you shouldn't worry.
But what if our privacy policy says that, for example, one of the big providers uses the word may 47 times in its terms of use.
We may use this data for data so.
47 times for me, it means I don't know what the hell they're doing with my data and this is not something a reasonable data controller should buy, right?
He should have the benefit of the doubt and ask such a provider.
Sorry this is not good enough for me.
I don't care if you're a global company, I will be the one responsible for my personal data.
If something happens to them.
And I'm sure that many small Assamese don't have 5 minutes to think about that, but they will have to think about it when a breach when data was misused and so on.
So if not sooner than I, I'm afraid.
Sometimes later they will have to think about it.

Of course, you may say when you, for example, if we take up security, what is better to have a small SMEs which has limited amounts of resources and knowledge and how well can they take care of their personal data?
Is it better perhaps to export it to a cloud which has huge resources and also in the field of security can provide much better and higher level of security measures?
So I guess there are a lot of open questions.
What is in a way better and security of course is only one.
Part of data protection.
A lot of people still mix those two points, particularly in Slovenian, because the the terms are a bit very similar.
Securities of course, only a part of data protection.
You can have very well secured personal data, but that doesn't mean that you protect him.
Well, you might have them without legal ground.
You might be using them for some incompatible purposes, and so on.
But yeah, there are locked, encrypted and so on.
There really secure that doesn't help you very much.
This is only a part of greater protection.
And of course, as soon as you transfer personal data to some third jurisdictions, I think you should know what the rules are over there, right?
Can some other law enforcement agents you get to your personal data?
Can some civil proceedings be opened against and your company and your branches and get your personal data and so on.

And of course, many clients of cloud computing services do not recognized rightfully the some of the specific trick risks which are associated with cloud computing such as the for example, multi tenancy issues.
The issue of location transparency that we really know where our personal data is processed.
As I said, data erasure.

Security mechanisms, for example, we have very strict requirements in the law about logging every access to data, and it's quite questionable whether a lot of data cloud providers ensure that kind of security, which is in some countries required by law.
All in all, in 2010 and 11 there was such a huge demand for opinions from data protection community to say OK, what does the law say about personal data?
There's a number of services which are very interesting to me, but I don't know where I bridge the law or not.
If I use them so please give us some guidance, some opinions on.
Who should I trust and who not to trust basically and the first response is?
For probably the ones from Denmark and Norway, which were already quite negative, especially about the cases of municipalities trying to use Google Apps.
And then you should rather negative opinions because they asked a very simple questions to this municipality.
Where will your personal data be stored and processed?
When will they be erased and how, where?
How will they be secured and the company Authority Municipality set well.

This was given to us by these cloud providers so I guess you can find the answers in there and I said we will not be finding these answers but you will have to provide us with these answers until you do.
I'm sorry we will not let you use this kind of service.
Not to mention that they were trying to use it for a sensitive personal data which enjoys a higher degree of protection in European Union.

Off quite somewhat similar opinion was the one of the German DPS, the Schleswig Holstein, who raised serious concerns about the Safe Harbor agreements, and it should sort of a call for independent certification.
Following this particular opinions from particularly PS A so called support Memorandum was adopted by the International group, the So called Berlin Group.

With this long name, Joan is also and me are both in this group, so it is really pleasure to see Joan again and this bowling group adopted another important opinion which shows its international dimension and sort of international consensus of those authorities that are in charge of data protection.
Legislation.
What is on the European Union level?
A opinion was also adopted this year in July.

This one is really good because it contains very specific recommendations of what a contract should consist of between a cloud provider and a cloud user, and it's in a way shows consensus from EU regulators.
I will briefly go through through those two first the support.
I'm random.
Provides general recommendations and its starting point is very simple and blunt.
Basically it says that cloud computing offers a number of very positive aspects, but it also must not as such lead to a lowering of data protection standards.
If we allow this, then all sorts of new technologies, paradigms and everything will diminish.
Basically, the current regime of protection of personal data, which is do not forget a fundamental human right.
The recommendations then go on and our focus to particular.
Stakeholders.

As for data controllers, it advises them to use risk analysis alone, or if they do not know how to do one with the use and help of a third party to cloud providers, it calls for greater transparency for greater and more concise security measures, accountability, portability and so on.
To legislators to have a thorough look at the existing legislation and to reconsider whether the existing legislation is able to withstand the wave of new paradigms and so on.
And basically, this is already happening in the EU.
The directive, the very old 1 from 95, is currently in the process of revision and it said that in two, 3 four years time it will be probably replaced by new regulation as it stands.
As for supervisory authorities, the call is for greater awareness, raising activities and of course its supervision.
And the opinion also stresses the importance of further research and development in the field, such as sealed cloud homomorphic encryption and so on.
It also gives a lot of accent to the issues of certification standardization as a way of going forward forward.
Besides the general recommendation.
It also lists 27 very more particular recommendations, such as the issue of location transparency that at anytime the data control should be aware where actually in the world his or her.
I mean their personal data is being processed, which includes any possible subcontractor subprocesses.
That risk analysis should be carried out before embarking on a cloud solution.
That data subject rights, so the individual whose personal data is being processed.
Has certain rights and this must be implemented even if you are in the cloud and so on.

So if you want to have a thorough look at them, I have links at the end of the presentation and right now the International Conference of Data Protection regulators is going on in Uruguay, and this opinion of bowling groups will probably serve as a basis for their recommendations, so this will finally be a worldwide response from the data protection community.
The second opinion was the Article 29 working party opinion.
This group joins the European Regulators plus European Commission and European Data protection supervisor.
As I said, it contains detailed requests regarding the content of contract between user and provider and some of its statements are quite important.
For example, that imbalance of contractor contractual powers should not be seen as an excuse for data controllers.
As a data controller you cannot say well.
I just accepted these terms of use and I should be OK.
It's not my fault right?
If the data got lost or stolen or publicly published, and so on.
It also notes that the some of the problems with the existing Safe Harbor Agreement, which covers transfer of personal data from EU to USA companies.
It says that national legislation may contain higher requirements and additional requirements and that this agreement does not cover transfer to other countries.
For example, if a USA Safe Harbor Company also uses data centers from India, Brazilian and so on.
Then you are not completely covered with this.
And that any company that exports personal data should not merely rely on a statement that, hey, I'm a Safe Harbor company.
You are OK with us.
And the Article 29 party actually recommends a higher standard of contractual relationships, which is basically the so-called standard contractual clauses.
Sort of typical template contracts and BCR's for processors.
A particular tool which is still being developed.
Similar to the support memorandum also, this group recommends that the standardization certification and similar schemes could be a solution to this problem in the mid to long term.
And last of all, or maybe in between.
Also, our organization issued guidelines for our Slovenian companies and public institutions in cooperation with Cloud Security Alliance with its local chapter with Zotero Block from the Euro Cloud.
And with the Slovenian esaka chapter.

The aim of our guidelines is basically and mostly to raise awareness between data controllers to know what they are actually embarking upon and to offer a sort of a control is to be used by both data controllers in cloud providers to be able to check whether have they forgotten something really important before using a cloud solution.
It was issued in June.
It's also available in English.
And it of course depicts the cloud computing and it start.
It points out the main concerns that arise from the field of personal data protection.
It contains the Dimension control list and a couple of very practical examples that can be used.
It's intended as I said, for both for data controller and cloud provider.
Are the controls, however, are very minimal controls and it's basically something that every DPA in European Union would very probably agree.
We didn't want to set very high requirements in order not to.
Further this harmonize the requirements from the EU data protection law, so these are basically very low level minimum requirements.
The ones that you should not forget if you are going into the cloud.
And every control also has a short implementation guideline to be sure.
OK, I have implemented this control.
And as I said, if this manual controls are not implemented, you should really reconsider going to the cloud.
Examples of control.
So I did not list all of them.
You can have a look at them in peace.
For example, the client should always know which categories of personal data he is actually giving to a cloud provider.
He should be informed at all times about all the subprocesses that a cloud provider is using.
This is very tightly connected to the principle of knowing the physical location of data processing and the so called location transparency principle.
We also believe that a risk analysis should be.
Carried out before using such a service.
And for example, encryption as a as one of the security controls wherever data are going through unprotected communication networks.
This is as I said, only a set of minimum controls from the guidelines.
And as I set a number of practical examples, we have an example of a.
All and medium enterprise which is thinking about using a cloud based software suit and case gives examples about the location transparency.
The case is about exporting data to third countries and this EM is faced with standard terms of use which are hardly able to negotiate.
The second one is the example of a public institution trying to use the cloud services.
Then we have two enterprise level examples focusing mostly on information and data security cases.
Then I asked me and a cloud based CRM solution.
And the last example is from the viewpoint of a local cloud provider.
So how can he use the guidelines to help him improve his transparency towards its customers and so on?
Done.
I.
Only have one last light, not to be too long if you ask me.
The solution to cloud in terms of how to exploit its benefits, its perceived.

Positive aspects that it brings and on the other hand, how to preserve privacy and data protection is to reestablish the trust which is, I think, something that we are still on the path towards and such as I said, cloud computing as such should not be something that lowers achieve data protection standards.
And without trust, I don't think legally and practically the cloud can actually live up to its promises.
But when you speak about trust, we have to know the trust is not only about security.
Trust is about reliability.
It's about fairness, Accessibility, also, data protection, and so on.
This is 1.
My particular example.
I tried to copy 8 gigabytes and they say it would take me 48,000 days, so such reliability of a data cloud provider is not really something you would like to when you have very critical data.
And it's a question that is common in data protection world.
It's revolving about the concept of privacy by design, so it's how to use the positive aspects of something.
But still, how to preserve privacy?
I think that.

The old balances that were brought upon with the directive, and so on cannot survive in the digital age as such, and sometimes we will have to resort to third parties that can bring this balance back between especially small data controllers and very big global players acting as data processors.
So these mechanisms, I guess, involved standardization, certification, even privacy seals and so on.
So for me as a.
Cloud potential user.
I would just like to know whom to trust.
You have this kind of seal you have this kind of standard you have this kind of certificate.
OK I will trust you and I don't want to check every single aspect.
I trust you because somebody else who knows more than me was able to check you regularly and I have no issues with that.
We are still on the path towards this.
There's a number of standardization activities going on in the ISA world as the Cloud Security Alliance and developing all sorts of tools and schemes and so on.
So I guess it's in a way a matter of time, and which one will survive over the others.
But I think this is the solution to regaining this balance which was.
How lossed and.
But not least, I think you will understand this even if it's not in English.
OK, maybe we don't have that kind of competence is, but we do have some competencies and we will carry out inspections also with cloud computing and I hope you are prepared for that so.
I thank you for your attention and if you have any questions, I'll be more than willing to reply.
Thank you.
In one of your recent slides I if I understand it properly, are you sad as a minimalist thundered?
If I?
If I understand it properly, just the information to the data owner.
Basically it's enough.
I mean for me this will be not sufficient because I think I would like to have a control over it whenever there is a transaction somewhere.
I would like to be notified in advance and give my I don't know any kind of constant.
Of that, or maybe even the next step would be I controlled the site.
I mean there might be a couple of sites that are available and I would like to have a full control of it where my data reside at any moment I mean.
For me this would be a lot of you know weak, but I understand you're working on it and it's a minimal.
Could you confirm this?
Have understood it properly?
First of all, your claim is completely legitimate as a data controller you should have and currently on the legal framework you do have control over your processing providers.
However, again with the cloud, it's really hard to imagine how would you actually implement this control.
If you are a small data controller.
If you take the example again of a small school and Google.
I don't think Google would allow this cool to visit its data centers and see how the lights are blinking and so on.
This is why I say that, yes, legally you have the right and one of I didn't put up all of the controls.

There are some other controls which says that the provider cloud providers should either allow data controller to inspect its premises and data security practices or grant this option to 1/3 trusted party to which they will agree upon.
Or either it can also embark on a regular independent third party audits and publish its results and so on.
I think this is something that will solve this problem of a small data controller, not even be able to assess whether and what is going on with the data processor.
So yeah, this is these are some of the minimal requirements.
As I said, not not all of them are on the slide.
But you are quite correct.
Data Controller currently has the legal right to supervise any of its data processors.
Yeah, how it can be done in practice is another question.
I'm just reading.
111 month old statement from from Viviane Reading saying Europe needs to think big.
The cloud strategy which will enhance trusted innovative computing solutions in booster competitive digital single market where European feels safe.
That means a swift adoption of the new data protection framework, which the Commission proposed earlier this year and the development of safe and fair contract terms and conditions.

And I was listening to her just a couple of days ago in Luxembourg saying that the one of the biggest obstacle is that we have 28 legislations also on data protection and that she, together with the Vice President Ali Cruise, would do the all.
All their best.
That by the end of 2015 we would achieve which is something like a common understanding of this legislation.
Not 28 legislation but one, and I think this is.
This is something that.
Is coming from from the US because they they don't have to cope with that many legislations as we have you think it's feasible or not.
By the end of 215.
Yes, I think it can be probably done.
It involves a huge number of debates, and so on.
And of course the interests are very diverge and so on.

So I think it it could be done, but rest assured that I'm quite positive that this new regulation will not mention cloud computing, not in a single word, so don't expect something very concrete on cloud computing.
I'm quite sure that the regulation is here to stay for a very long time, and it cannot be that specific.
It has to remain technologically neutral, so I can bet you whatever you want, you will not see those two words in the regulation, however, which is completely normal.

However, it is still a regulation, and the difference from the directive is that a regulation is directly applicable in every Member State, whereas the directive needs to be transposed into national laws, and there are all sorts of divergences can occur, and they have.
For example, it is quite true if you look, for example at the Google Street View case.
It was, although we should have sort of the same legislation.
Europe, it was accepted very differently in different States and.
So the regulation is definitely an effort to to bring more harmonization, but as I said that the talks will be long, discussions will be very deeper, so I hope that we can have it by the end of 2015.

Legislation.

A opinion was also adopted this year in July.

I'm random.
